rdfs:label: Phone
ds:description: A minimal speech segment that possesses distinct physical or perceptual properties.

rdfs:label: Vowel
ds:description: A speech sound which is produced with a relatively open vocal tract and vibration of the vocal cords.

rdfs:label: Short-vowel
ds:description: A vowel sound that is pronounced in a short form.

rdfs:label: Long-vowel
ds:description: A vowel sound that is pronounced in a long form.

rdfs:label: Diphthong
ds:description: A sound formed by the combination of two vowels.

rdfs:label: Consonant
ds:description: A basic speech sound which is produced with an obstructed vocal tract and which can be combined with a vowel to form a syllable, or which can form itself or together with another consonant a syllable.

rdfs:label: Grapheme
ds:description: The smallest contrastive or meaningful unit in writing which matches either a phoneme, a syllable or a morpheme.
ds:comment: Has different definitions, but this one is used in the domain of neuroimaging and useful as such as it is distinct from a character in an alphabetic language (letter) but useful. See Bouhani paper and https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17586801.2019.1697412 (a combined definition and interesting discussion)

rdfs:label: Logogram
ds:description: A sign or character representing a morpheme, word or phrase, such as those used in shorthand and some writing systems.

rdfs:label: Letter
ds:description: A character that is the smallest meaningful or functional unit in an alphabetic writing system.
ds:comment: Represent both letter and Grapheme since letter is not confusable and useful in contrast to a concept such as Grapheme, while also having individual use (word length)

rdfs:label: Noncharacter
ds:description: A character which does not hold any meaning or contain any regularity in a writing system.

rdfs:label: Pseudocharacter
ds:description: A logogram-like character that contains components/radicals of existing logograms but which is not a known logogram.

rdfs:label: Mora
ds:description: A basic timing unit in the phonology of some spoken languages, equal to or shorter than a syllable.

rdfs:label: Morpheme
ds:description: A meaningful unit of a language that cannot be further divided.

rdfs:label: Lemma
ds:description: The canonical form, dictionary form, or citation form of a set of word forms.

rdfs:label: Bigram
ds:description: A pair of two consecutive written units such as letters, syllables, or words.
ds:comment: Bigrams have been suggested as a unit that is explicitely represented in human visual cortex (citation deheane)

rdfs:label: Radical
ds:description: A graphical component of a Chinese character under which the character is traditionally listed in a Chinese dictionary.

rdfs:label: Language-item-property
ds:description: A property of a linguistic unit within a framework of language analysis.
ds:comment: All these properties should be grouped with a language item

rdfs:label: Language-item-form
ds:description: The form of a language unit.
ds:comment: Following https://www.w3.org/2016/05/ontolex/ (which is not an ontology for language annotation but an ontology for lexical entries in ontologies) we do not make the form of langauage inherent to language items but instead attach it separately. The word itself is a concept, but it can be expressed in multiple forms. The same is true for a sentence, phrase, clause. For some units it is more complicated, but there is a spoken form of a letter, grapheme, etc. and depending on the writing system there might be a written form of a vowel or consonant. This distinction increases flexibility

rdfs:label: Written-form
ds:description: The expression of a language unit through a system of writing.

rdfs:label: Canonical-written-form
ds:description: The accepted spelling of a word in a given language.

rdfs:label: Pseudohomophone-form
ds:description: A deliberate generated written-form of a word that is not in accordance with an orthographic system but is pronounced as the word based on direct grapheme to phoneme conversion.

rdfs:label: Incorrect-written-form
ds:description: An incorrect written form that does not correspond to the canonical or the pronounced form of a word, but from which the word can still be identified as such.

rdfs:label: Spoken-form
ds:description: The expression of a language item as a sound produced by a human or artificially made to sound as if produced by a human.

rdfs:label: Canonical-spoken-form
ds:description: The regular spoken form of a language item.
ds:comment: Should be commonly used, although there is no language without accent, only use regional spoken form when this is relevant in context of the dataset

rdfs:label: Regional-spoken-form
ds:description: A spoken form of a language item pronounced with a regional accent.
ds:comment: Use when relevant in context of dataset

rdfs:label: Mispronounced-spoken-form
ds:description: A mispronunciation of a language item which can still be identified.

rdfs:label: Morpheme-property
ds:description: A property of a morpheme.
ds:comment: Morphemes can be categorized based on position, function, and type. A morpheme property can be applied to a Morpheme

rdfs:label: Morphene-type
ds:description: The type of a morpheme.

rdfs:label: Free-morpheme-type
ds:description: A morpheme type that can function as a word.

rdfs:label: Bound-morpheme-type
ds:description: A morpheme type that cannot be a word itself, such as prefixes and suffixes.

rdfs:label: Morpheme-function
ds:description: The function of a morpheme.

rdfs:label: Word-formation-function
ds:description: Creating a new word.

rdfs:label: Derivation
ds:description: Changing the meaning of a word, usually by adding an affix.
ds:comment: Derivation changes the meaning of a word, for instance, reverses the meaning, or changes intensity. We do not cover all the semantic types of changes that can be the result of morphological changes, but instead give a higher level categorization. Further specification might depend on a more semantic schema.

rdfs:label: Change-word-class
ds:description: Changing the word class or part of speech a word belongs to.
ds:comment: Combine with Lexical-role to express what the process has resulted in. Follows Category-changer concept in GOLD, but instead of extending further HED can fulfil the same function by tagging it together with a lexical role.

rdfs:label: Compound
ds:description: To join with another free morpheme to form a more complex word.

rdfs:label: Inflective-morphological-function
ds:description: Changing the grammatical function.

rdfs:label: Conjugate
ds:description: Identifying the voice, mood, tense, number, gender, and person of a verb.
ds:comment: Combine with grammatical category what the morpheme adjusted (can be multiple in aggulating languages)

rdfs:label: Decline
ds:description: Marking the number, case, gender, or class of nouns, pronouns, adjectives, and articles.
ds:comment: Combine with grammatical category what the morpheme adjusted (can be multiple in aggulating languages)

rdfs:label: Morphological-position
ds:description: The position a morpheme takes relative to the free morpheme of a word.

rdfs:label: Affix
ds:description: A morpheme that is attached to a word stem to form a new word or word form.
ds:comment: Affix is a categorization of morpheme based on its position. In OLIA this is a subclass of Morpheme. However, there are other categorizations of morphemes, based on how they change the stem of the word, which are categorized in OLIA as Morphological processes, such as Clitization, reduplication. However, since these all say something about how the morpheme is applied to the word, we believe these fit better together under the position tag.

rdfs:label: Prefix
ds:description: Position of a morpheme at the beginning of a word.

rdfs:label: Suffix
ds:description: Position of a morpheme at the end of a word.

rdfs:label: Infix
ds:description: Position of a morpheme in the middle of a word.

rdfs:label: Circumfix
ds:description: Position of a morpheme split in two parts, one placed at the start of a word, the other at the end.

rdfs:label: Non-concatenative-morphology
ds:description: Process of word formation and inflection in which the stem  may be modified (without stringing morphemes together sequentially).

rdfs:label: Apophony
ds:description: Regular vowel variation.

rdfs:label: Conversion
ds:description: No change (where a morphological change might be expected based on regular grammar).

rdfs:label: Transfixation
ds:description: Interdigitation of vowel and consonant morphemes.

rdfs:label: Reduplication
ds:description: Duplication of all or part of the root word.

rdfs:label: Truncation
ds:description: Removal of phonological material from root.

rdfs:label: Clitic-morphological-position
ds:description: A morpheme that has syntactic characteristics of a word, but which is phonologically dependent on another word.

rdfs:label: Lexical-role
ds:description: The role a language item takes in a vocabulary, like part of speech.
ds:comment: Sometimes applies to a word, or to a phrase that fulfils a lexical role

rdfs:label: Noun
ds:description: Referring to a specific object or set of objects (living creatures, places, actions, qualities, states of existence, ideas etc.

rdfs:label: Verb
ds:description: Generally conveying an action, occurrence, or state of being  and makes up the main part of the predicate of a sentence.

rdfs:label: Auxiliary-verb
ds:description: A verb devoid of lexical content that combines with another verb to realize certain grammatical functions (e.g. expression of tense, passive voice, negation, interrogation).

rdfs:label: Modal-verb
ds:description: An auxiliary verb that combines with another verb and expresses necessity, wish or possibility.

rdfs:label: Transitive-verb
ds:description: A verb that requires one or more objects to receive the action.

rdfs:label: Intransative-verb
ds:description: A verb that does not require an object.

rdfs:label: Unergative-verb
ds:description: An intransitive verb whose subject is an agent.

rdfs:label: Unaccusative-verb
ds:description: An intransitive verb whose subject is a theme (i.e. affected by the process the verb expresses).

rdfs:label: Psychological-verb
ds:description: A verb that takes two arguments, an experiencer and a theme.

rdfs:label: Adjective
ds:description: A word that describes or defines a noun or noun phrase.

rdfs:label: Adverb
ds:description: Modifying or qualifying an adjective, verb, or other adverb or a word group, expressing a relation of place, time, circumstance, manner, cause, degree, etc.

rdfs:label: Pronoun
ds:description: A word or a group of words that may stand for a noun or noun phrase.

rdfs:label: Personal-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun associated with a grammatical person.

rdfs:label: Possesive-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun referring to the possession of a grammatical person.

rdfs:label: Relative-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun that marks a relative clause.

rdfs:label: Demonstrative-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun used to indicate which entities are being referred to and to distinguish those entities from others.

rdfs:label: Reflexive-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun that refers to another noun or pronoun within the same sentence.

rdfs:label: Indefinite-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun lacking a specific referent or having generic meaning.

rdfs:label: Interrogative-pronoun
ds:description: Pronoun which prompts a question.

rdfs:label: Determiner
ds:description: Determining the kind of reference a noun or noun group has.

rdfs:label: Article
ds:description: A class of dedicated words that are used with noun phrases to mark the identifiability of the referents of the noun phrases.

rdfs:label: Possesive-determiner
ds:description: Determining the ownership of a noun or noun phrase.

rdfs:label: Adposition
ds:description: Accompanying an noun to express a spatial or temporal relation.

rdfs:label: Preposition
ds:description: Preceding a noun or noun phrase expressing a spatial or temporal relation to another word or element in the clause.

rdfs:label: Postposition
ds:description: Appearing after a noun or noun phrase expressing a spatial or temporal relation to another word or element in the clause.

rdfs:label: Circumposition
ds:description: Appearing before and after a noun or noun phrase expressing spatial or temporal relation to another word or element in the clause.

rdfs:label: Classifier
ds:description: An item that accompanies nouns and can be considered to classify a noun depending on the type of its referent.
ds:comment: Classifiers are subdivided by GOLD into Nominal, Noun and Numeral classifiers. OLIA lists classifier under morphosyntactic category unique, a class for categories with unique or small membership. Classifiers can have different functions across languages. In Chinese specifically, count and mass Classifiers are distinguished. Given that these might be language specific and there is no agreement in existing standards we have not added subcategories for now.

rdfs:label: Conjunction
ds:description: Connecting clauses or sentences or to coordinate words in the same clause.

rdfs:label: Coordinating-conjunction
ds:description: Coordinates elements that are equal to each other.

rdfs:label: Complementizer
ds:description: Marks a finite or non- finite clause as functioning as a complement

rdfs:label: Negation-word
ds:description: Expressing falsity of a clause or sentence

rdfs:label: Particle
ds:description: Must be associated with another word or phrase to impart meaning.
ds:comment: In Olia they use the term Unique and recommends not using particle because of differing definitions. Particle has an older use but a the modern definition is well defined, and word particle is used in neuroimaging studies (https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11347875/, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22341872/)

rdfs:label: Quantifier
ds:description: Expressing a reference definite or indefinite number or amount.
dc:source: Adapted from D. Terence Langendoen, General ontology of Linguistic description, http://purl.org/linguistics/gold

rdfs:label: Numeral
ds:description: Expressing a number or relation to a number.
dc:source: Adapted from D. Terence Langendoen, General ontology of Linguistic description, http://purl.org/linguistics/gold

rdfs:label: Interjection
ds:description: A word or expression that occurs as an utterance on its own and expresses a spontaneous feeling or reaction.

rdfs:label: Clause-type
ds:description: The type of a clause

rdfs:label: Independent-clause
ds:description: Containing a subject and verb but can be a sentence on its own.

rdfs:label: Dependent-clause
ds:description: Containing a subject and verb and cannot be a sentence on its own.

rdfs:label: Phrase-role
ds:description: The role of phrase.

rdfs:label: Noun-phrase
ds:description: Functioning in a sentence as subject, object, or prepositional object.

rdfs:label: Verb-phrase
ds:description: Containing the verb and any direct or indirect object, but not the subject.

rdfs:label: Adjective-phrase
ds:description: Headed by an adjective.

rdfs:label: Adverb-phrase
ds:description: Functioning as an adverb in a sentence.

rdfs:label: Prepositional-phrase
ds:description: Consisting of a preposition and its complement.

rdfs:label: Syntactic-role
ds:description: Role a language-item takes in syntax.

rdfs:label: Head
ds:description: Word that determines the syntactic category of a phrase.

rdfs:label: Complement
ds:description: The constituent selected by a head.

rdfs:label: Object
ds:description: Complement of a verbal head.

rdfs:label: Subject
ds:description: Basic constituent of a clause about which something is said; typically, but not necessarily, associated with a specific case (most often nominative).

rdfs:label: Modifier
ds:description: Optional element in a phrase or a clause that specifies a noun or acts as an adjunct

rdfs:label: Adjunct
ds:description: Optional element in a clause or sentence that provides information about the temporal, local (etc.) circumstances under which an event occurred.

rdfs:label: Predicate
ds:description: Basic constituent of a clause that expresses a property or condition of the subject or an action performed by it.

rdfs:label: Secondary-predicate
ds:description: Adjectival or prepositional predicate that is not the main (verbal) predicate of the clause and refers to the subject or the object, as either depictive (indicating a state) or resultative (indicating the event's result on the object)

rdfs:label: Grammatical-category
ds:description: Grammatical category of a word, usually marked through inflection.
ds:comment: Features in Eagles, Olia has no top level features

rdfs:label: Tense
ds:description: Deictic category of verbal morphology that situates an event (on an imaginary timeline) as either anterior, posterior or simultaneous to a reference point, prototypically time of speech

rdfs:label: Past-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event anterior to time of speech.

rdfs:label: Remote-past-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event in the distant past.

rdfs:label: Recent-past-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event in the recent past.

rdfs:label: Pluperfect
ds:description: Referring to a past event relative to another reference point (not the time of speech)

rdfs:label: Present-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event that takes place at time of speech.

rdfs:label: Future-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event posterior to time of speech.

rdfs:label: Near-future-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event shortly after time of speech.

rdfs:label: Remote-future-tense
ds:description: Referring to an event in the remote future.

rdfs:label: Future-perfect
ds:description: Referring to a future event relative to another reference point (not the time of speech).

rdfs:label: Non-past-tense
ds:description: Referring to both a present or future event.

rdfs:label: Non-future-tense
ds:description: Referring to both a past or present event.

rdfs:label: Aspect
ds:description: Non-deictic category of verbal morphology that describes the internal temporal contour of an event and presents it for instance as ongoing or completed.

rdfs:label: Perfective-aspect
ds:description: Presenting a completed event.

rdfs:label: Imperfective-aspect
ds:description: Presenting an ongoing or unfolding or repeated or habitual event.

rdfs:label: Mood
ds:description: Non-deictic category of verbal morphology that expresses speakers’ attitudes as regards the possibility, probability/likelihood, desirability, necessity, factuality etc. of the event.

rdfs:label: Subjunctive
ds:description: Used in dependent clauses to discussing imaginary or hypothetical events and situations, expressing opinions or emotions, or making polite requests, among other uses.

rdfs:label: Conditional
ds:description: Used for speaking of an event whose realization is dependent upon another condition.

rdfs:label: Imperative
ds:description: Expresses direct commands, prohibitions, and requests.

rdfs:label: Countability
ds:description: A grammatical category that determines how the quantity of a concept is expressed.
ds:comment: Countability feature in olia no definition

rdfs:label: Uncountable
ds:description: Syntactic property of nouns that makes their referents undifferentiated units.

rdfs:label: Countable
ds:description: Syntactic property of nouns that can be modified by quantities (expressed by grammatical number, e.g. singular, plural)

rdfs:label: Grammatical-number
ds:description: Formal feature of several word classes (e.g., nouns, pronouns, adjectives, verbs) that expresses or marks count distinctions, such as one vs. two vs. three or more.

rdfs:label: Singular
ds:description: Representing one instance of a concept.

rdfs:label: Plural
ds:description: Representing multiple instances of a concept.

rdfs:label: Dual
ds:description: Representing exactly two instances of a concept.

rdfs:label: Trial
ds:description: Representing exactly three instances of a concept.

rdfs:label: Paucal
ds:description: Representing a few, or small number of instances of a concept.

rdfs:label: Singulative
ds:description: Representing one instance of a concept through modifying the standard collective.

rdfs:label: Collective
ds:description: Not representing a specific number.

rdfs:label: Noun-class
ds:description: Formal category of nouns based on characteristic features of their referents, such as gender, animacy, shape, location or directionality.
ds:comment: Eagles only has gender as does olia. In Olia gender feature also encompasses animacy.

rdfs:label: Case
ds:description: Formal feature of several word classes (e.g., nouns, pronouns, adjectives, determiners) that identifies their syntactic function.

rdfs:label: Nominative
ds:description: Generally marks the subject of a verb, or a predicate nominal or adjective, as opposed to its object, or other verb arguments.

rdfs:label: Accusative
ds:description: Used to indicate the direct object of a transitive verb.

rdfs:label: Dative
ds:description: Used to indicate the recipient or beneficiary of an action.

rdfs:label: Ablative
ds:description: Used to express motion away from something, among other uses.

rdfs:label: Genitive
ds:description: Used to indicate attributive relations between nouns among other uses.

rdfs:label: Language-item-frequency
ds:description: The frequency with which a unit occurs in a language, or a particular context for that language e.g. formal, news articles, children's television, etc.

rdfs:label: Word-frequency
ds:description: The frequency with which a word occurs in a language, or a particular context for that language e.g. formal, news articles, children's television, etc.

rdfs:label: Bigram-frequency
ds:description: The frequency with which a bigram occurs in a language, or a particular context for that language e.g. formal, news articles, children's television, etc.

rdfs:label: Language-unit-probability
ds:description: The probability of a specific language unit occurring in a specific context.

rdfs:label: Cloze-probability
ds:description: The proportion of people who fill a gap in given sentence with a given word.

rdfs:label: Orthographic-neighborhood-size
ds:description: The number of closely resembling word-forms.

rdfs:label: Language-property
ds:description: A property relating to a system of communication  used by a particular group of people.

rdfs:label: Morphological-language-type
ds:description: Morphological property relating to a specific system of communication used by a particular group of people.

rdfs:label: Analytic-language-type
ds:description: Rarely using affixes, resulting in a low morheme per word ratio.

rdfs:label: Morphological-isolating-type
ds:description: Having a morpheme per word ratio close to one.

rdfs:label: Morphological-synthetic-type
ds:description: Having a higher morpheme per word ratio.

rdfs:label: Morphological-agglutinating-type
ds:description: Words are formed by stringing together morphemes wherby each one corresponds to a single grammatical feature.

rdfs:label: Morphological-polysynthetic-type
ds:description: Can encode multiple constituents such as subject, verb, object, etc. into a single word.

rdfs:label: Morphological-fusional-type
ds:description: Have a tendency to use a single inflectional morpheme to denote multiple grammatical, syntactic, or semantic features.

rdfs:label: Orthographic-type
ds:description: The type of unit each symbol serves to represent in written language.
ds:comment: Classification of writing systems is complex, and these categories are not universally accepted, mainly because most writing systems have characteristics of multiple of these categories. However, most writing systems have an overall tendency towards one of these categories, and so the categories can be useful to see how large differences are managed by the individuals who speak them. But it is normal that a writing system does not cleanly fit into any of these categories.

rdfs:label: Segmental-or-Alphabetic-type
ds:description: Representing approcimately phoneme per character.
ds:comment: These can be further subdivided based on other characteristics but these are most commonly used in cognition research, and relevant in research into dyslexia

rdfs:label: Shallow-orthographic-type
ds:description: Having a one-to-one correspondence between sounds (phonemes) and the letters (graphemes) that represent them.

rdfs:label: Deep-orthographical-type
ds:description: Not having a one-to-one correspondence between sounds (phonemes) and the letters (graphemes) that represent them.

rdfs:label: Logographic-type
ds:description: Representing an entire spoken word per character.

rdfs:label: Syllabary-type
ds:description: Representing one syllable per character.

rdfs:label: Grammatical-relationship
ds:description: Grammatical relationship between language items.

rdfs:label: Agreement-with
ds:description: Inflectional adjustment to match grammatical category (e.g. case, number, gender) of.

rdfs:label: Levenshtein-distance-to
ds:description: The minimum number of single-character edits to change into.

rdfs:label: Levenshtein-distance-to#
ds:description: Integers 0 and up

rdfs:label: Hamming-distance-to
ds:description: The minimum number of substitutions required to change one string into another string of equal length.

rdfs:label: Hamming-distance-to#
ds:description: Integers 0 and up

rdfs:label: Language
ds:description: A specific system of communication, with a vocabulary and grammar, which is used by a particular community or in a country.
ds:comment: Langue, has been suggested as a term to refer to a specific language, while the term language in general refers to the high level concept of language and its general properties. However, this has never been widely adopted. In context of the HED Language as a Item works.

rdfs:label: Indo-European-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages native to the majority of Europe, the Iranian plateau, and the northern Indian subcontinent.

rdfs:label: Germanic-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages originating in Northwestern and Central Europe and Scandinavia, currently spoken mainly in Europe, North America, Oceania and Southern Africa

rdfs:label: English
ds:description: A Germanic Language which is spoken in the United Kingdom, parts of North America, and Oceania and is used in parts of Africa, Asia and Oceania as an adminastrative language.

rdfs:label: German
ds:description: A Germanic Language which is mainly spoken in Western and Central Europe.

rdfs:label: Dutch
ds:description: A Germanic Language which is spoken in parts of Western Europe, South America and the Caribbean islands.

rdfs:label: Danish
ds:description: A Germanic language, mainly spoken in Denmark

rdfs:label: Icelandic
ds:description: A Germanic language mainly spoken in Iceland

rdfs:label: Swedish
ds:description: A Germanic language mainly spoken ín Sweden and parts of Finland.

rdfs:label: Norwegian
ds:description: A Germanic language mainly spoken in Norway.

rdfs:label: Romance-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages directly descending from Vulgar Latin.

rdfs:label: Spanish
ds:description: A Romance language spoken in Spain and large parts of the Americas.

rdfs:label: French
ds:description: A Romance language spoken in parts of Western Europe, North America and Africa, and is used as an adminatrative or official language in parts of the world.

rdfs:label: Italian
ds:description: A Romance language mainly spoken in Italy and parts of Switzerland.

rdfs:label: Portuguese
ds:description: A Romance language spoken in Portugal and part of South America (Brazil) and is used as administrative language in other parts of the world.

rdfs:label: Galician
ds:description: A Romance language mainly spoken in Galicia.

rdfs:label: Catalan
ds:description: A Romance language spoken in Andorra, and several autonomous communities in Eastern Spain as well as a department in Southern France.

rdfs:label: Romanian
ds:description: A Romance language spoken in Romania and Moldova as well as small communities in Bulgaria, Hungary, Serbia and Ukraine.

rdfs:label: Gallo-Rhaetian-language
ds:description: A group of historically related Romance varieties spoken in Switzerland and Northern Italy.

rdfs:label: Slavic-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages originating in Eastern Europe.

rdfs:label: Russian
ds:description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Europe and used in parts of Eastern Europe, West and Central Asia.

rdfs:label: Croatian
ds:description: A slavic language spoken mainly in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and parts of Serbia.

rdfs:label: Czech
ds:description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in the Czech Republic.

rdfs:label: Polish
ds:description: A slavic language spoken mainly in Poland.

rdfs:label: Slovak
ds:description: A slavic language spoken mainly in Slovakia.

rdfs:label: Ukrainian
ds:description: A slavic language spoken mainly in Ukraine.

rdfs:label: Bulgarian
ds:description: A slavic language spoken mainly in Bulgaria.

rdfs:label: Macedonian
ds:description: A slavic language spoken mainly in North Macedonia.

rdfs:label: Baltic-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages originating in Northeastern Europe.

rdfs:label: Lithuanian
ds:description: A baltic language spoken mainly in Lithuania.

rdfs:label: Latvian
ds:description: A baltic language spoken mainly in Latvia.

rdfs:label: Sino-Tibetan-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages spoken in Asia.

rdfs:label: Sinitic
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in China.

rdfs:label: Mandarin-Chinese
ds:description: A group of Chinese language dialects that are natively spoken in most of northern and southwestern China

rdfs:label: Standard-Chinese
ds:description: A modern standard form of Mandarin Chinese which is the official Language of mainland China.

rdfs:label: Wu-Chinese
ds:description: A Sinitic language mainly spoken in Shanghai, Zhejiang Province, and the part of Jiangsu Province south of the Yangtze River

rdfs:label: Xiang-Chinese
ds:description: A Sinitic language mainly spoken in Hunan province, northern Guangxi and parts of Guizhou, Guangdong, Sichuan, Jiangxi and Hubei provinces

rdfs:label: Gan-Chinese
ds:description: A Sinitic language mainly spoken in Jiangxi province , and parts of Hunan, Hubei, Anhui, and Fujian.

rdfs:label: Yue-Chinese
ds:description: A group of Sinitic languages mainly spoken Southern China

rdfs:label: Cantonese
ds:description: A Sinitic Language mainly spoken southeastern China, Hong Kong and Macau.

rdfs:label: Burmo-Qiangic-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of language mainly spoken in Southwest China and Myanmar.

rdfs:label: Burmese
ds:description: A Burmo Qiangic language mainly spoken in Myanmar

rdfs:label: Atlantic-Congo-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in South, and parts of Central and West Africa.

rdfs:label: Swahili
ds:description: An atlantic congo language mainly spoken in Tanzania, Kenya and Mozambique.

rdfs:label: Afroasiatic-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in West Asia, North Africa, the Hord of Africa and parts of the Sahara and Sahel.

rdfs:label: Arabic
ds:description: An Afroasiatic language spoken mainly in Northern Africa and Western Asia.

rdfs:label: Hebrew
ds:description: An Afroasiatic language mainly spoken in Isreal.

rdfs:label: Austronesian-language
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southeast Asi, Madagascar, the islands of the Pacific Ocean and Taiwan.

rdfs:label: Malay
ds:description: An Austronesian language manily spoken in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, East Timor and parts of Thailand.

rdfs:label: Austroasiatic
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southeast Asia, South Asia and East Asia.

rdfs:label: Vietnamese
ds:description: An Austroasiatic language mainly spoken in Vietnam.

rdfs:label: Dravidian
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southern India, Northeast Sri Lanka Southwest Pakistan and some regions of Nepal.

rdfs:label: Tamil
ds:description: A Dravidian Language spoken the Indian state Tamil Nadu, Puducherry and Sri Lanka and Singapore.

rdfs:label: Japonic
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Japan and the Ryukyu Islands

rdfs:label: Japanese
ds:description: A Japonic language mainly spoken in Japan.

rdfs:label: Koreanic
ds:description: A system of commication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Korea.

rdfs:label: Korean
ds:description: A Koreanic language mainly spoken in Korea.

rdfs:label: Tai-Kadai
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southeast Asia, Southern China, and Northeastern India.

rdfs:label: Thai
ds:description: A Tai Kadai language mainly spoken in Central Thailand.

rdfs:label: Turkic
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages spoken in parts of Eurasia such as Eastern Europe, Southern Europe, Central Asia, East Asia, North Asia and West Asia.

rdfs:label: Turkish
ds:description: A Turkish language mainly spoken in Turkey and Northern Cyprus.

rdfs:label: Uralic
ds:description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in part of Europe and North Asia.

rdfs:label: Finnish
ds:description: An Uralic language mainly spoken in Finland.

rdfs:label: Estonian
ds:description: An Uralic Language mainly spoken in Estonia.

rdfs:label: Hungarian
ds:description: An Uralic Language mainly spoken in Hungary.
